metadata.title: Erectile Dysfunction and Exercise
description: Erectile dysfunction (ED) is the physical component of sexual dysfunction in men with normal energy drive (libido) for sexual activity. Patients with ED report the inability to achieve an erection or maintain adequate rigidity of their penis for satisfactory sexual intercourse(1,2,3,4)
ED is primarily a vascular disease. Among men in the United States, ED is associated with increased cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk and premature mortality risk(24,26)

The prevalence of ED is associated with reduced physical activity. Authors of a cross-sectional  study (n = 692 men, 50 to 85 years of age) in the United States found that for every 30 minutes per day of moderate-to-vigorous  physical activity, participants had 43% reduced odds of having ED(25)

A program that includes regular aerobic exercise, weight loss, and improved antioxidant status may help to improve erectile function, as well as improve overall vascular health, in men with ED(5,6,9,27)
This Clinical Review focuses on the role of therapeutic exercise for men with ED

Additional information on therapeutic exercise training in men who may have coexisting ED can be found in  Clinical Review ... Diabetes Mellitus, Type 2, and Exercise  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: 5000008912;  Clinical Review ... Peripheral Artery Disease and Exercise  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: 5000015198;  Clinical Review ... Angina Pectoris, Stable  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: 5000010242; and  Clinical Review ... Multiple Sclerosis and Exercise  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: 5000015215
reimbursement: Reimbursement for exercise therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific special agencies, issues, or information regarding reimbursement have been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: The primary complaint is inadequate erection for sexual intercourse –In a 2006 survey of men in Canada (N = 3,921 men aged 40 to 88 years) seen by primary care physicians, the prevalence of ED was 49.4%(2)

Metabolic syndrome (MetS): this is a diagnostic category that includes abdominal (central) obesity, hypertriglyceridemia, hyperglycemia/diabetes, low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, and hypertension(28)
Patients may present with reduced aerobic fitness due to inadequate physical activity(25)  Causes, Pathophysiology, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Exam may be normal in asymptomatic patients with ED(2)
Stop the evaluation if the patient experiences shortness of breath, chest pain, abnormal fatigue, tachycardia, syncope, arrhythmia, or dizziness. Contact the referring physician immediately
Red flag complications that warrant stopping the evaluation and referral back to physician(2) –Anemia –Enlarged lymph nodes –Fever –Testicular mass –Unintentional/unexplained weight loss

causes: The etiology of ED is primarily vascular disease (i.e., diminished endothelium-dependent  vasodilation) in the penilearteries(1,7,8)
Arteriogenic/vasculogenic–Hypertension(7)–Peripheral vascular disease(7)–Ischemic heart disease(7)–Diabetes(7,22)–Atherosclerosis(22)–Corporal veno-occlusive  mechanism dysfunction–Pelvic irradiation

Neurogenic(7)–Spinal cord injury(10,22)–Multiple sclerosis(7)–Multiple system atrophy (MSA)–Cerebral injury–Parkinson disease(22)–Alzheimer disease(22)–Efferent nerve damage–Temporal lobe epilepsy–Peripheral neuropathy(7)
Surgical(7,8)–Radical prostatectomy(15)–Cystectomy–Anterior urethroplasty(20)–Perineal, penile, urethral, or pelvic surgery–Rectum resection–Aorto-iliac  surgery
Psychogenic(7,8)–Major life-event  stress(22)–Depression(22)–Performance anxiety(22)–Partner-related  difficulties–History of sexual abuse or other traumatic event

Anatomical or structural(7,8)–Peyronie disease(18)-It is estimated that 8% of men with Peyronie’s disease are under the age of 40 years, with 40% of these menexperiencing ED(18)–Cavernous fibrosis–Hypospadias–Epispadias–Micropenis–Penile fracture
Medication side effects(7,8)–Antihypertensives such as thiazides and clonidine, antiandrogens, cimetidine–Antiarrhythmics–Antidepressants such as SSRIs–Antipsychotics
pathogenesis: Atherosclerosis with endothelial damage to the penile arteries supplying the corpus cavernosum is the most commonunderlying pathophysiology of arteriogenic ED(1,8)

In nearly all cases of arteriogenic ED, the penile arteries fail to dilate adequately because the endothelial cells do notrelease sufficient amounts of vasoactive relaxing factors such as nitric oxide (NO) into the cells of the corpus cavernosafollowing parasympathetic stimulation(1,7,8)

NO-induced  vasodilatation is impaired due to reduced intracavernosal cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) levels,which are responsible for smooth muscle relaxation, influx of blood into the penis, and controlling the outflow of blood,which causes engorgement(7,8)
Other contributors to vasodilation during erection include vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) and prostaglandins E1 andE2(7,8)

Spinal reflexes and neurohumoral pathways also facilitate penile erection. This central mechanism is triggered bynoncholinergic, nonadrenergic neurons in the brain that release NO and activate the paraventricular nucleus (PVN) of thehypothalamus. ED secondary to decreased libido is associated with reduced activation of the PVN(7,8)
The impairment of endothelium-dependent  vasodilationin ED is shared with the pathophysiology of CVD and MetS.(9,28)Patients with ED should thus be evaluated for potential CVD
risk factors: Diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and increased fasting glucose level are independently associated with risk of ED(2,8)
Conditions that promote atherosclerosis in penile arteries (e.g., hyperlipidemia, cigarette smoking, hypertension,hyperglycemia)(7)
Psychiatric or psychological disorders(8)–Depression, anxiety, history of sexual abuse(22)
Tobacco, illicit drug, and alcohol use(8)
Radical prostatectomy or transurethral resection of the prostate(8)
Endocrine disorders, thyroid disease, gonadal disease(8)
Bicycle riding may be associated with increased risk of ED due to perineal compression and possible trauma of thepudendal nerve within Alcock's canal(29)

overall contraindications precautions: Ensure that physician’s referral specifies exercise prescription/training
Uncontrolled hypertension (diastolic blood pressure [BP] greater than 110 mmHg and/or systolic BP greater than 180 mmHg at rest)
Tachycardia/bradycardia: heart rate (HR) greater than 100 beats/min. or less than 50 beats/min. at rest
Uncontrolled diabetes (e.g., hyperglycemia greater than 250 mg/dL, ketonuria)
Severe orthopedic conditions that would restrict safe exercise
Uncontrolled metabolic conditions, such as acute thyroiditis, hypokalemia, hyperkalemia, hypovolemia
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/ Plan of Care  (10)

contraindications precautions to examina: Exam may be normal in asymptomatic patients with ED(2)
Stop the evaluation if the patient experiences shortness of breath, chest pain, abnormal fatigue, tachycardia, syncope, arrhythmia, or dizziness. Contact the referring physician immediately
Red flag complications that warrant stopping the evaluation and referral back to physician(2) –Anemia –Enlarged lymph nodes –Fever –Testicular mass –Unintentional/unexplained weight loss

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Etiology of illness -When was ED diagnosed in the patient? -Was onset associated with preexisting conditions and lifestyle factors that increase ED risk, such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease, obesity, or physical inactivity? -Was onset related to pelvic/genitourinary trauma or surgery? -Screen patient for cardiovascular risk factors -What is patient’s current level of confidence in erectile function?

surgical management: Surgical management:  Has the patient received an implantable penile prosthesis, such as an inflatable device? Were there any surgical complications (e.g., infection)? Has the device failed?(8)
course of treatment.medications: Clinical practice guidelines published by the American College of Physicians recommend phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitors as the firstline  medical treatment for ED(8) PDE5 inhibitors have demonstrated effectiveness in patients with diabetes mellitus, type 2 (DM2) and central neurological disorders(3,4) PDE5 inhibitors are taken in anticipation of sexual intercourse. The evidence is insufficient to compare the efficacy and adverse effects of different PDE5 inhibitors because there are few headto-head  comparison trials(16) The American College of Physicians guidelines and Alberta Medical Association Guidelines state that PDE5 inhibitors in conjunction with prescribed nitrate medications are an absolute contraindication. PDE5 inhibitors can combine with cardiac nitrates to cause excessive vasodilation and hypotension, which can result in death(16) Testosterone therapy can be prescribed via intramuscular injections, transdermal gels, or via oral prescription for individuals with low testosterone; however, the American College of Physicians does not recommend for, or against, hormonal treatment in the management of patients with ED(16)
diagnostic tests completed: The American College of Physicians guidelines do not recommend for, or against, routine use of hormonal blood

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting). The majority of the assessment is to rule out any underlying functional impairments that can impede the patient’s ability to safely participate in an aerobic exercise and conditioning program as indicated
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height, weight, and BMI. Compare to normative data. ED is associated with central obesity(28) and increased BMI(19)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess need for and appropriateness of assistive device. ED is not associated with impaired mobility; however, an underlying medical condition or previous surgery may require the need for an assistive/ adaptive device
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic sitting and standing balance as indicated. Balance impairments may be present due to comorbidities. Impairments that reduce balance are not a direct result of ED
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: In 2012, the Princeton III Consensus Expert Panel Conference published recommendations regarding the evaluation and management of patients with ED and cardiovascular disease(17) -Patients should undergo stress testing and an analysis of their exercise abilities in order to thoroughly assess their cardiovascular health status prior to prescribing treatment for ED -All patients should be properly assessed prior to prescription of any medications for ED since patients with cardiovascular disease may be asymptomatic
Assess HR and BP at rest, during activity, and post activity

Perform graded exercise test (GET) if facility has the necessary equipment and monitoring devices. If not, use the 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) and monitor patient’s level of exertion with dyspnea scale and/or Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale.(10) Sedentary patients may have reduced aerobic work capacity (AWC)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess distal pedal pulses and note any asymmetry or diminished palpation. Assess ankle-brachial  index (ABI) and note any abnormality Assess dermatomes and myotomes in bilateral upper extremity (UE) and lower extremity (LE), as indicatedAssess basic ADLs and level of assistance required to safely and independently perform them, as indicated. Use Timed Up and Go (TUG) test and/or Timed Up and Down Stairs (TUDS) test to assess functional limitations
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess gait for any significant deviations, decreased speed, etc. Assess safety with Dynamic Gait Index (DGI)Assess bilateral UE and LE joint mobility for crepitus, contractures, or hypermobility, as indicatedAssess UE, LE, and trunk for abnormal tone (flaccidity or spasticity), as indicated
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess gross functional strength with manual muscle testing (MMT) or handheld dynamometer (if tone is normal), including trunk strength and core stability. Assess handgrip strength with dynamometer
relevant tests and measures.posture: Document the patient’s posture in sitting and standing, noting any asymmetry
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess gross functional flexibility and ROM with goniometry or by observation of movement for bilateral UEs and LEs
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess bilateral deep tendon reflexes and protective righting responses to challenges in balance, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess sensation to light touch and proprioception in bilateral UE and LE, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –International Index of Erectile Function–5  (IIEF-5) -A self-administered  questionnaire designed to measure the severity of ED and assess treatment-related changeserectile function, orgasmic function, sexual desire, intercourse satisfaction, and overall satisfaction -On a scale from 1 to 30, scores can range from 26–30 points (no ED), 17–21  points (mild ED), 12–16  points (mild to moderate ED), 8–11  points (moderate ED), 5–7 (severe ED) –Quality of Erection Questionnaire (QEQ) -6-item,  patient-reported  questionnaire -The total score is converted to a 0–100 scale(11) –The Sexual Encounter Profile (SEP) is a 5-question  survey that is meant to be completed after each attempt of sexualerection, individual satisfaction, and couple satisfaction domains(12)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess as indicated for comorbidities. Is the patient alert and oriented x 4? Any noted deficits should not be considered a direct result of ED, but they may affect the patient’s ability to compensate(7)

other: Physical therapy guidelines are lacking for treating ED symptoms
Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the referring physician
Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment when implementing therapeutic exercise or when using physical or electrotherapeutic modalities
Comorbidities will likely influence the need for targeted treatment and should be addressed per physician’s orders and findings on physical exam

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: ED/decreased aerobic fitness secondary to physicallyinactive lifestyle will most likely be the primary focus of physical therapy intervention. Goals for physical therapy treatment include the following: Patient education Improve aerobic endurance Increase functional strength Reduce functional impairments, such as decreased balance associated with comorbidities (e.g., DM neuropathy) Weight-loss  management program Pelvic floor muscle strengthening (15)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Cancer (e.g., testicular, prostate) Genitourinary trauma or surgery Psychogenic causes
prognosis: Oral medications for the treatment of ED have high success rates –Authors of a cohort study (n = 952) in the United States found that of patients who reported no successful intercourse attempts during a 4-week  baseline period, 81% had at least one successful intercourse attempt following a 12-week treatment period with tadalafil(13) –Authors of a 2011 literature review found that patients treated with sildenafil or vardenafil had high success rates. However, tadalafil had higher patient preference because its longer duration of action (36 hours) increased the time available to initiate sexual activity(14) –Authors of a 2016 systematic review and meta-analysis  of 7 studies (n = 478 participants allocated to aerobic, pelvic, or combined exercise interventions, or usual care) found that short-term  and long-term  aerobic exercise of moderate-to-vigorous  intensity may reduce the severity of ED(27)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physician specialist in urology or sexologyHabitual dietary flavonoid (fruit and vegetable) intake is associated with reduced incidence of ED, based on large epidemiological studies(30,31) Behavioral psychologist/psychiatrist for counseling and to address any underlying psychiatric conditions associated with ED
other considerations: Patients with ED and central neurological disease or concomitant libido impairment caused by depression may not benefit from PDE5 inhibitors(4) ›The severity of ED and improvement with treatment may be assessed with the IIEF-5  and the Sexual Encounter Profile(7)
treatment summary: Scientific evidence suggests that a comprehensive approach to CVD risk reduction will improve overall vascular health, including sexual function(8)
Aerobic exercise –Aerobic exercise training and general physical activity appear to be effective as complementary treatment for ED(27)
PFM rehabilitation increases the intracavernosal pressure, which may improve the ability to maintain an erection(23)

Patients should be properly educated on the red flag signs associated with prescribed medications for ED. These include dizziness, shortness of breath, arrhythmia, tachycardia, and syncope. Patients also need to be instructed to contact their physician immediately should any of these occur(8)

A home exercise walking program can decrease the severity of symptoms of ED in men who have had a myocardial infarction (MI) –Based on an RCT (n = 100 men with recent MI) in Brazil(21) –Patients were randomized into a home exercise group and a control group -Home exercise group ambulated unsupervised for 4 times a week for a month after discharge from the hospital -Patients were advised to warmup for 5 minutes, followed by an endurance walk training period that began with 20 minutes during the first week and increased progressively by 5 minutes every other week. A 5-minute  cool-down  was performed after the endurance period -Control group received only usual post-MI  care -Results showed that after 30 days the men in the home exercise group had a 71% decrease in the severity of ED, whereas the control group reported a 9% increase in ED . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Reduced aerobic exercise/ activity and AWCReduced frequency and severity of ED symptoms; reduced negative impact on HRQoLFunctional training _ Individualized prescription of exercise program for improving aerobic fitness _ _ Encourage compliance with medical and psychological managementGradually progress frequency, duration, and intensity of exercise to recommended levels(10)Provide patient with simple instructions for home exercise. Referral to other specialists, as appropriate .

maintenance or prevention: Continue with prescribed home exercise program which includes moderate, daily physical activity and any other patient-specific  exercises(2)

Recommended lifestyle changes and reduction in risk factors associated with ED(2,8) Patients should be encouraged to quit smoking, participate in regular physical activity, continue with weight management, reduce or stop alcohol intake, and abstain from illicit drugs(8) Maintain a healthy diet, particularly by eating fruits and vegetables with flavonoids(17,30,31)
Patients need to be encouraged to manage their risk factors associated with DM and CVD(8)
Encourage patients to seek and receive psychological counseling if ED is associated with psychological factors(8)

Followup with referring physician regarding any adverse effects associated with prescribed medications(2) Patients taking testosterone replacement need annual prostate examinations and blood testing to monitor hormone, liver enzymes, hemoglobin, and PSA levels(8) The frequency of testing should be increased for patients at a higher risk for prostate cancer, including Blacks and those with a family history(8)
patient education: Mayo Clinic website, “Diseases and conditions: Erectile dysfunction,” https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/erectile-dysfunction/symptoms-causes/syc-20355776 Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
